On physical examination, temperature is 38.5 °C (101.3 °F); other vital signs are normal. Scattered crackles are heard bilaterally on pulmonary auscultation.

Blastomycosis is a dimorphic, round, budding yeast that most often manifests as a primary pulmonary infection in immunocompetent persons.
Blastomycosis is found primarily along the Mississippi and Ohio River valleys but can be found as far north as Wisconsin and Minnesota and as far south as Florida.

Exposure to soil is the most commonly identified risk factor. The organism is typically diagnosed on respiratory secretions demonstrating large, round, budding yeast, with the mother cell connecting to the daughter cell. ) is the third most frequent cause of invasive fungal infections in immunocompromised persons, but it is rarely seen in immunocompetent persons. Particularly at risk are patients with neutropenia, diabetes mellitus, and acidosis. Mucormycosis has five major clinical forms: (1) rhinocerebral; (2) pulmonary; (3) abdominal, pelvic, gastric, gastrointestinal; (4) primary cutaneous; and (5) disseminated. Because laboratory studies are nonspecific, diagnosis relies on a high index of suspicion in a patient with appropriate risk factors and evidence of tissue invasion, including the characteristic appearance of broad, nonseptate hyphae with acute-angle branches.
